questions.text: A 31-year-old man met with a road traffic accident. When he was brought to the hospital, he was declared brain dead. Organ harvesting was planned after informed consent. What is the grade given to this patient based on the American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) classification?
questions.solution:
The brain dead patients come under the American Society of Anesthesiologists classification (ASA) grade VI.

ASA grading is a physical status examination that strongly correlates with the perioperative risk. It assesses and communicates a patient’s pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: The postmortem examination of an elderly man with chest pain showed a myocardial infarction in the area marked below. Occlusion of which of the following arteries is the cause of myocardial infarction in this patient?
questions.solution:
The area marked in the above image is the anterolateral wall of the left ventricle. This area is suppleid by the anterior interventricular artery which is likely to be occluded in this patient.

The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus ) of the ascending aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the atrioventricular groove. 

It divides into two branches in the coronary sulcus. They are:

  • The anterior interventricular branch or left anterior descending artery (LAD) - Is the continuation of the left coronary artery. Gives anterior septal branches, anterior ventricular branches, and diagonal artery.
  • Circumflex branch (Options A)- Curves left in the atrioventricular groove and continues around the left cardiac border to reach the posterior part of the groove. It terminates in the crux in most hearts but may continue as a posterior interventricular artery in some individuals.

The left coronary artery supplies most of the left ventricle, a narrow strip of the right ventricle, the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum, and most of the left atrium.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus. It first passes between the right atrium and the pulmonary trunk. On reaching the atrioventricular groove, it descends down vertically and curves around the right border of the heart to reach the inferior (posterior) part of the groove. The artery ends a little left of the cardiac crux by joining the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. 

Branches of the right coronary artery are :

  • Right conal artery
  • Branches to the anterior part of the atrium and ventricles.
  • Right marginal artery (acute marginal artery) (Options C & D)
  • Posterior interventricular artery

The right coronary artery supplies most of the right ventricles, a small part of the diaphragmatic aspect of the left ventricle, the posteroinferior third of the interventricular septum, the right atrium and part of the left atrium, sinoatrial node, and atrioventricular node.

Dominance is determined by the vessel which supplies the posterior interventricular artery. If the posterior interventricular artery is derived from the left coronary artery it is called left dominance, if it is derived from the right coronary artery it is called right dominance.

questions.text: The image below shows a clinical finding on the skin of a patient with a particular condition. What is its first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
The given image shows burrows that are found in scabies. The first-line treatment for scabies is topical permethrin.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus.

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: A child who has been saved from a human trafficking ring has been subjected to a medical examination. The child has no recollection of his identity. His age is estimated to be around 14 years. Which of the following bones from this x-ray help in confirmation of this child's age?
questions.solution:
From the given x-ray, the first metacarpal and pisiform help in confirming this child's age. The child's age is estimated to be between 12 to 17 years. 

In the x-ray photograph of the wrist and hand, the lower epiphyses of the first metacarpals are not united with the shaft. The epiphyses of the metacarpal bones fuse with the shaft between the age of 15 to 17 years. The pisiform has ossified. This makes the minimum age of the child to be 12 years. Hence, the child's age will be between 12 and 17 years.

Hence, the pisiform and metacarpals help in estimating the age of the child in this case. 

Ossification centres of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 1–3 months
  • Hamate:  2–4 months
  • Triquetral: 2–3 years
  • Lunate: 3–4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4–6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5–6 years
  • Pisiform: 10–12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18–19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5–6 years of age and fuses at 17–18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18 years.

questions.text: An elderly man presents for evaluation following an episode of syncope the same day. He reports having fatigue, chest pain, and exertional breathlessness. 2D-echo shows left ventricular hypertrophy, with an aortic valve area of 0.8 sq. cm. What will be the character of the pulse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of aortic stenosis (AS), which is associated with the characteristic pulsus parvus et tardus.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused by the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis:

  • Exertional dyspnea: This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure. This causes exertional dyspnea.
  • Angina pectoris: It occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery 
  • Syncope: It occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

As LV systole gets prolonged, the aortic component of S2 may become synchronous with the pulmonary component, or there may be a paradoxical splitting of S2, where the aortic component follows the pulmonary component. The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids. 

Severe AS is defined as the aortic valve area <1 cm2. Patients even with severe AS may be asymptomatic as the left ventricle undergoes hypertrophy to increase the intraventricular pressure and maintain the stroke volume. Symptomatic AS is an indication for valve replacement.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. It is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, severe asthma, massive pulmonary embolism, and tension pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Grading of Aortic Stenosis

Grading of stenosis

Area of aortic valve

Mild

1.5 – 2 sq cm

Moderate

1 – 1.5 sq cm

Severe

< 1 sq cm

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L1 woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with pruritus on the palms and soles for 2 weeks. She also had yellowish discoloration of the sclera. Her total bilirubin level was 3.8 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels were elevated, and serum transaminase levels were normal. She also reports that she had similar complaints during the previous pregnancy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is a reversible cholestatic disease occurring in the 2nd or 3rd trimester. It is characterized by pruritus (worse on palms and soles and at the night) and icterus. It is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, cholestatic hepatosis, and icterus gravidarum.

Hyperbilirubinemia results from the retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated, but seldom exceed 250 U/L. Total and fasting serum bile acid concentrations are elevated. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management comprises antihistamines, topical emollients, cholestyramine, and ursodeoxycholic acid.

Other options:

Option B: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy manifests mostly in the last trimester of pregnancy with nausea, vomiting, anorexia, epigastric pain, and progressive jaundice. There may be hypertension, protein­uria, and edema. There is moderate to severe liver dysfunction with hypofi­brinogenemia, hypoalbuminemia, hypocholesterolemia, and prolonged clotting times. Serum bilirubin level is usually <10 mg/dL, and serum transaminases are ele­vated but <1000 U/L.

Option C: Acute viral hepatitis is usually asymptomatic. When symptomatic, it presents with nausea, vomiting, and malaise, followed by jaundice. Low-grade fever may be present. Serum bilirubin rises, and transaminase levels vary.

Option D: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is commonly associated with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hyperlipidemia­ syndrome. It is usually asymptomatic with elevated transaminases.

questions.text: A young man complains of knee pain and a locking sensation in his knees for 3 days. He noticed this following a game of football a few days ago. He does not recall any acute event that precipitated the pain. The test shown in the image is done. What is the name of the test?
questions.solution:
The test done in the image is Apley's test. It is used to detect injuries to the menisci and it is done with the patient lying in the prone position.

A meniscal tear is a split or tear in the meniscus following a rotational or shearing force. The medial meniscus is affected more commonly than the lateral. Sometimes, it may be a vertical tear. If the separated fragment stays attached at the front and back, it is known as a bucket handle tear.

It presents as insidious or acute(in severe cases) onset pain, swelling, popping/catching/locking/giving out the sensation of the knee following a twisting injury to the knee. A plain X-ray appears normal, but MRI confirms the diagnosis.

Apley's test: This test is performed with a prone patient, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. Reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Other options:

Lachman test - done to detect anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is in the position between flexion and extension. The femur is stabilized by one hand and the other hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia.

McMurray test: Done to detect menisci injuries. The patient's knee is completely flexed while he lies supine. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint and the leg is internally and externally rotated with the other hand. The leg is then slowly extended. Meniscal injury presents as a palpable or audible click.

Thessaly test: With the affected knee flexed to 20 degrees and the foot placed flat on the ground, the patient takes his full weight on that leg while being supported by the examiner. The patient is then asked to twist his or her body to one side and then to the other three times. This test has shown a high diagnostic accuracy rate at the level of 95% in detecting meniscal tears.

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates the therapeutic index of a drug?

ED50 - Median effective dose

LD50 - Median lethal dose
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio. The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI in the following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 or TD50/ED50

where LD50 is the mean lethal dose, TD50 is the mean toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose 

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50)

  • LD50 is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die.
  • In human trials, TD50 can be considered. It is the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
  • Larger the LD50 or TD50, the safer the drug. 

Median effective dose (ED50)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect
  • ED50 is the quantity of a drug that can produce the desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

The therapeutic window refers to a range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: A patient developed a thyroid storm following radioiodine treatment. During the management, he is being given 5 drops of potassium iodide every 6 hours. This inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by:
questions.solution:
Potassium iodide inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis by Wolff- Chaikoff effect. Large doses of iodide inhibit organic binding of the iodide and hence decrease thyroid hormone synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Jod-Basedow phenomenon is the increased synthesis of thyroid hormone following exposure to iodine.

Option C: Second wind phenomenon is seen in patients with McArdle disease. After a short break from strenuous exercise, the patients can continue exercise without pain

Option D: Thyrotoxicosis factitia is the ingestion of excess thyroid hormone leading to thyrotoxicosis.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair of neurotransmitter and precursor.
questions.solution:
Option A is incorrect. Melatonin is a metabolic derivative of tryptophan, not tyrosine.

The important tryptophan metabolites are serotonin (option C) and melatonin. Tryptophan is hydroxylated by tryptophan hydroxylase to form 5-hydroxy tryptophan. This undergoes decarboxylation to form serotonin or 5-hydroxy tryptamine.

Serotonin is further converted to melatonin in the pineal gland via acetylation and methylation. S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) acts as the methyl donor. Melatonin is involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle.

Other options:

Option B: Glutamate is decarboxylated by l-glutamate decarboxylase to form the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA.

Option D: The catecholamines are synthe­sized from tyrosine. Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosine hydroxylase to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine or DOPA. DOPA is decarboxylated to dopamine, which is hydroxylated to form norepinephrine.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with loud, raspy, and noisy breathing. His mother also says that his voice has become hoarse over the past 3-4 months. He was born at term through an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of laryngeal papilloma or recurrent respiratory papillomatosis.

It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papilloma DNA virus (HPV) types 6 and 11. Squamous papillomas can be seen in children, juvenile papillomatosis (as in this case), and in adults, adult-onset papilloma. 

It is thought that the patients acquire this condition from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus infection during birth. It is usually seen in the supraglottic and glottic regions. Less commonly, the subglottis, trachea, and bronchi may be involved.

Clinically, the patient is typically a young child 3-5 years of age. They may present with hoarseness of voice, stridor, and breathing difficulty. The disease recurs requiring repeated surgical and medical management throughout childhood. Rarely, they may undergo malignant change. 

It is diagnosed using flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and may later be confirmed by direct laryngoscopy or rigid bronchoscopy and biopsy.

Treatment of recurrent respiratory papillomatosis:

  • Surgical management with excision using a CO2 laser
  • Medical management using interferon-alpha has been tried as an adjuvant, but it is associated with significant side effects 

The adult-onset version is usually less severe and does not recur after surgical removal. It affects males more than females and presents between the ages of 30-50 years. 

Other options: 

Option A - Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition of the larynx that manifests at birth and disappears by the age of 2 years. Babies present with stridor on crying that relieves in the prone position. 

The following image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis of laryngomalacia:

 

Option B - Reinke's edema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The following image shows Reinke's edema:

 

Option C - Vocal cord nodules occur at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. This occurs due to vocal trauma that happens when the patient speaks in low tones or high intensities for prolonged periods.

questions.text: A patient is prepared for a minor procedure in the ophthalmology outpatient department. The following instruments are assembled in the tray. Which of the following glands is involved in the pathology for which this procedure is performed?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments represents the chalazion set which is used to perform incision and curettage of a chalazion.

The chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation. Excessive tightening of the screw can lead to pressure necrosis. The solid blade is placed externally on the skin and the ring-shaped blade is on the inner conjunctival surface.

A chalazion scoop/curette is another instrument specific to the incision and curettage of a chalazion. It has a small round cup-shaped tip with sharp margins attached to a narrow handle. It is used to scoop out the contents of the chalazion and curette the base after making a vertical incision opening up the wall of the chalazion from its palpebral surface.

A chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of the Meibomian gland. A chalazion may be single or multiple. They may reduce in size, but the complete spontaneous resolution does not occur. Treatment of chalazion includes injection of intralesional triamcinolone or curettage.

Sometimes, the chalazion may become secondarily infected and form a hordeolum internum. This is an acute suppurative inflammation of the meibomian gland, associated with blockage of the duct. It presents with a swelling similar to a chalazion, but more inflamed with pus pointing on the conjunctival surface. It can be treated conservatively with oral antibiotics and hot fomentation or with an incision and drainage. An image of hordeolum internum is shown below.

Other options :

Options A and D: The gland of Wolfring and the gland of Krause are the accessory conjunctival glands and are not involved in a chalazion.

Option B: Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done.

questions.text: Following a term Caesarean delivery, a newborn presents with fast breathing. On examination, respiratory rate is 68/min and the chest is clear. A chest X-ray shows fluid in the intralobar fissures and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most prominent diagnosis in a newborn with tachypnea, clear chest, and given X-ray findings of intralobar fluid and perihilar pulmonary vascular markings is transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN).

TTN is a self-limited cause of tachypnea associated with delayed absorption of fetal lung fluid. It is characterized by early-onset tachypnea that is relieved by minimal oxygen supplementation (<40%). There maybe retractions, expiratory grunting, or cyanosis which also resolves with oxygen. On examination, the chest is clear without crackles or wheeze.

The chest X-ray shows prominent pulmonary vascular markings, fluid in the intralobar fissures, and, rarely, small pleural effusions.

Most infants recover usually within 3 days with supportive care.

Other options:

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease- Radiographic findings like hypoaeration, diffuse reticulo-granular pattern, and air bronchograms will be seen.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in term or post-term infants. The infants are meconium-stained and may be depressed and require resuscitation at birth; The typical chest radiograph is characterized by patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of both lung fields, and hyperinflation.

Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia presents with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and bowel sounds heard in the chest wall.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of multiple motor and vocal tics for the past 18 months. His mother informed that sometimes the child would also utter socially unacceptable words suddenly during a conversation. The tics increased and decreased in frequency during this period. The child has normal social and academic skills. How do you manage?

choices.text: Psychoeducation with wait and watch strategy
Botulinum toxin injection to decrease tic severity

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Tourette's syndrome. In mild cases, which do not affect the academic or social life, the first-line of management, is to provide psychoeducation and follow a watch and wait strategy.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder named after the French neurologist Georges Gilles de la Tourette. The condition is characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to vocal tics that can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting or barking noises or shouted words, which may be obscenities.

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at the same time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before age 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis).

The management of Tourette's syndrome depends on the severity of the disease.

Mild cases:

  • In mild cases, where the disorder does not affect academic performance or social life, the first line of management is to provide psychoeducation, followed by a watch and wait strategy. A large proportion of patients the severity of tics wane in adult life becoming less of a medical problem.

Moderate to severe cases:

  • In moderate to severe cases, where the disorder significantly affects the child's academic performance and social life, the first line of management includes behavioral and psychological treatment.
  • Some commonly used methods for behavioral treatment include habit reversal, and exposure & response training.
  • In severe cases, both behavioral and pharmacological treatment may be provided.
  • Drugs commonly used include typical and atypical antipsychotics, nor-adrenergic agents.

questions.text: A prospective study is being conducted to study the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are more likely to smoke. So, smoking is also associated with exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. This problem can be tackled by all of the following methods except:
questions.solution:
This problem can be tackled by all of the following methods except blinding. The problem refers to a confounding factor, ie smoking. Confounding factors can be prevented or eliminated by randomization, matching, and restriction. 
 
A confounding factor is defined as the one associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. For example, a prospective study is being conducted to know the effect of alcohol on the development of lung cancer. However, individuals who drink alcohol are most likely to smoke. So, smoking is associated with the exposure. Also, smoking is an independent causative factor for lung cancer. Thus, smoking is a confounding factor.
 
In the above example, if the study is conducted without eliminating the confounding factor, then the result may falsely suggest that alcohol is a causative factor for lung cancer.  
 
Techniques to eliminate confounding factors include:
  • Randomization
  • Matching
  • Stratified randomization
  • Restriction
Randomization is the random allocation of the participants in experimental studies (Ex.randomized control trial) into the study group and control group.
 
Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (for example, case-control and cohort studies), is the process where the participants in two groups are matched based on factors such as age, gender, race, smoking status, etc. to eliminate the potential confounders.
 
Stratified randomization, which is also known as pre-stratification or blocking, is the process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups that internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants from each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.
 
Restriction: This method restricts the study to only those participants with particular characteristics. For example, a study can be restricted to participants of only one gender, race, age group, geographical area, disease severity, etc., thus eliminating the potential confounders.
 
Other options:
 
Blinding does not eliminate confounding factors. Blinding is done to eliminate the bias (such as subject bias, observer bias, or investigator bias).

questions.text: What is the dense zone of calcification seen at the metaphysis in scurvy?
questions.solution:
Dense zone of calcification at growing metaphysis seen in scurvy is known as Frankel's line.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: The apparatus shown below is used to estimate:
questions.solution:
The given image is that of Horrock’s apparatus which is used to determine the chlorine demand of water.

It consists of:

  • 6 white cups of 200 ml each
  • 1 black cup with a circular mark inside
  • 2 metal spoons -each holds 2g of bleaching powder
  • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
  • Two droppers
  • Starch-iodide indicator solution

The dose of bleaching powder required for disinfection of water can be calculated using this apparatus.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who serves in the military presents with a swelling in the natal cleft with occasional purulent discharge from it. He also complains of pain, and difficulty in sitting. On examination, a single point of discharge is seen. There is hair at the opening, but no feces are present. Per rectal examination has no significant findings.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a military personnel with swelling in the natal cleft associated with pain and discharge is suggestive of pilonidal sinus disease/jeep disease. 

Pilonidal sinus disease is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected.

The pilonidal sinus opening is seen usually in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. The other sites that they can be affected include the interdigital cleft and axilla.

Pathophysiology:

Buttock friction and shearing forces in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
  • A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.
  • Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.

Other options :

Options A - Hidradenitis suppurativa refers to follicular occlusion, folliculitis and secondary infection with skin flora. This leads to chronic suppurative, painful, skin abscesses, sinus tracts, and scarring. It usually occurs in skin containing apocrine glands, like the axillae and groins. It runs in the caudad direction while pilonidal sinus runs in a cephalad direction. They are usually found in the perineum while pilonidal sinus is found in the natal cleft. 

The following image shows a hidradenitis suppurativa lesion with multiple boils and points of discharge.

Option C - Anal fistula is an abnormal communication, that runs outwards from the anorectal lumen to an external opening on the skin of the perineum or buttocks. It presents with bloody discharge and in some cases feces in the sinus tract while a pilonidal abscess/sinus does not. The internal opening is usually palpated as a point of induration in rectal examination.

Options D - Postanal dermoid is a cystic condition that usually remains asymptomatic until adult life. Hair is not found in the sinus tract. The cyst is easily palpable on rectal examination. Pressure over the sacrococcygeal region with a finger in the rectum may cause a flow of sebaceous material. A bottle-necked cyst is visualized in the front of the coccyx upon injection of contrast media followed by radiography. Given the background of serving in the military, postanal dermoid is less likely to be the answer to this question.

questions.text: A young frequent traveler presented with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms were gradually worsening over the past 2 weeks. A widely used tube agglutination test was ordered for this patient. Which of the following statements is true regarding this test?

choices.text: High titre value in a single  test is confirmative
Increase in titre after one week indicates anamnestic response
Agglutination titre depends on the stage of the disease
Early antibiotic treatment shows good agglutination response

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of typhoid fever and the widely used tube agglutination test is the Widal test. In this test, the agglutination titer depends on the stage of the disease. 

Enteric fever (Typhoid fever) caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia, abdominal symptoms, headache, and malaise.

Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's sera. The antigens used in Widal's test include:
  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Paratyphoid O antigens cross-reacts with the typhoid O antigen due to the sharing of factor 12, hence O antibody cannot differentiate between the Salmonella types.

Interpretation: 

  • The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease:
    • Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. 
    • The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines gradually.
  • The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.
    • H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
    • The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks. 
  • The 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is highly significant as compared to a single high titer (Option A):
    • This is because, in persons who had a prior enteric fever, there is a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue), known as an anamnestic reaction.
    • Therefore, after a one-week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction. (Option B)
  • Cases treated early with antibiotics may show poor agglutinin response. (Option D)

questions.text: A 29-year-old man came with a history of jerky and hyperkinetic movements involving all parts of the body. His MRI shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. There is a significant family history with successive generations having symptoms at earlier ages of onset. The pedigree chart is given below. Identify this genetic phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario, with the family pedigree chart showing autosomal dominant inheritance points towards Huntington’s disease, and the genetic phenomenon seen here is anticipation. Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. 

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the striate neurons. It is caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the HTT gene located on chromosome 4. This results in jerky, hyperkinetic movements called chorea and dementia. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. Motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia. The HTT gene, on chromosome 4 encodes a protein called huntingtin. It has a stretch of repeats of the trinucleotide CAG. When the number of repeats is increased beyond normal, it is associated with Huntington's disease. More the repeats, earlier is its onset.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, and cortex. The lateral and 3rd ventricles may be dilated. There is a loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus on microscopic examination. The medium-sized, spiny neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter, along with enkephalin, dynorphin, and substance P are affected. Protein aggregates containing huntingtin can be seen in the neurons of the striatum and cerebral cortex. The chorea can be treated with dopamine-blocking agents like tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Option A: Each mitochondrion contains many copies of mtDNA, where deleterious mutations of mtDNA may affect a few, but not all the copies of mtDNA. Hence, individuals may harbor both wild-type and mutant mtDNA. This is known as heteroplasmy. Thus, when a cell containing both normal and mutant mtDNA divides, the proportion of the normal and mutant mtDNA in the daughter cells is variable. This explains why the expression of disorders resulting from mtDNA mutations is variable.

Option B: Genetic heterogeneity refers to the phenomenon where mutations at several different loci produce the same trait.

Option C: Variable expressivity refers to a similar genotype but a varying phenotype. The trait will be present in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals. Eg: varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).
